title: 110_hr5954
content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Project 112. Presumption of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112 is added to title 38, United States Code. This includes diseases incurred or aggravated by service, even without evidence during that period. Any diagnosed disease falls under this presumption. The presumption of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112 in title 38, United States Code includes any diagnosed disease that the Secretary determines warrants a presumption of service connection due to increased exposure to toxic agents during military service. The veteran may be eligible for service connection if they were subjected to a chemical or biological warfare test under Project 112 and develop a related disease. Veterans exposed to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and develop a related disease are presumed to have been exposed to toxic agents unless evidence proves otherwise. The Secretary will determine service connection eligibility through regulations. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases related to exposure to toxic agents during military service. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information when determining service connection for diseases related to exposure to toxic agents during military service, taking into account statistical significance, replicability, and peer review of results. For determining service connection related to exposure to toxic agents, the Secretary considers statistical significance, replicability, and peer review of results. An association between a disease and exposure to a toxic agent is considered positive if credible evidence outweighs evidence against it. If the presumption of service connection is removed, veterans awarded compensation may be affected. The removal of the presumption of service connection for a disease under this section will not affect veterans awarded compensation before the effective date of the removal. Survivors of veterans awarded dependency and indemnity compensation for the death resulting from the disease will also continue to receive compensation. The term 'Project 112' is defined in this section. The term 'Project 112' is defined as the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense or any other Federal agency from 1963 to 1973. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses related to chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must create regulations within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must provide all records of personnel exposed to such agents within 30 days. A report must be submitted within 1 year of enactment. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of enactment regarding Project 112. The report should detail costs, benefits, challenges, and information on Project 112 participants, addressing concerns held by the Department of Veterans Affairs and veterans. Project 112, also known as the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD, is the focus of a report to be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The report will address concerns regarding Project 112 participants and other issues raised by the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations.
